trans-unit.source: Azure App Service API app triggers
trans-unit.target: Azure App Service API app triggers

trans-unit.source: This article demonstrates how to implement triggers in an API App
trans-unit.target: This article demonstrates how to implement triggers in an API App

trans-unit.source: Azure App Service API app triggers
trans-unit.target: Azure App Service API app triggers

trans-unit.source: Overview
trans-unit.target: Overview

trans-unit.source: This article explains how to implement API app triggers and consume them from a Logic app.
trans-unit.target: This article explains how to implement API app triggers and consume them from a Logic app.

trans-unit.source: If you are new to <link><linkText>API apps</linkText><title></title></link> in <link><linkText>Azure App Service</linkText><title></title></link>, we recommend reading the multi-part series on <link><linkText>creating API apps</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: If you are new to <link><linkText>API apps</linkText><title></title></link> in <link><linkText>Azure App Service</linkText><title></title></link>, we recommend reading the multi-part series on <link><linkText>creating API apps</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: In addition, all of the code snippets in this topic are copied from the <link><linkText>FileWatcher API App code sample</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: In addition, all of the code snippets in this topic are copied from the <link><linkText>FileWatcher API App code sample</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Note that you'll need to download the following nuget package for the code in this article to build and run: <link><linkText>http://www.nuget.org/packages/Microsoft.Azure.AppService.ApiApps.Service/</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: Note that you'll need to download the following nuget package for the code in this article to build and run: <link><linkText>http://www.nuget.org/packages/Microsoft.Azure.AppService.ApiApps.Service/</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: What are API app triggers?
trans-unit.target: What are API app triggers?

trans-unit.source: It's a common scenario for an API app to fire an event so that clients of the API app can take the appropriate action in response to the event.
trans-unit.target: It's a common scenario for an API app to fire an event so that clients of the API app can take the appropriate action in response to the event.

trans-unit.source: The REST API based mechanism that supports this scenario is called an API app trigger.
trans-unit.target: The REST API based mechanism that supports this scenario is called an API app trigger.

trans-unit.source: For example, let's say your client code is using the <link><linkText>Twitter Connector API app</linkText><title></title></link> and your code needs to perform an action based on new tweets that contain specific words.
trans-unit.target: For example, let's say your client code is using the <link><linkText>Twitter Connector API app</linkText><title></title></link> and your code needs to perform an action based on new tweets that contain specific words.

trans-unit.source: In this case, you might set up a poll or push trigger to facilitate this need.
trans-unit.target: In this case, you might set up a poll or push trigger to facilitate this need.

trans-unit.source: Poll trigger versus push trigger
trans-unit.target: Poll trigger versus push trigger

trans-unit.source: Currently, two types of triggers are supported:
trans-unit.target: Currently, two types of triggers are supported:

trans-unit.source: Poll trigger - Client polls the API app for notification of an event having been fired
trans-unit.target: Poll trigger - Client polls the API app for notification of an event having been fired

trans-unit.source: Push trigger - Client is notified by the API app when an event fires
trans-unit.target: Push trigger - Client is notified by the API app when an event fires

trans-unit.source: Poll trigger
trans-unit.target: Poll trigger

trans-unit.source: A poll trigger is implemented as a regular REST API and expects its clients (such as a Logic app) to poll it in order to get notification.
trans-unit.target: A poll trigger is implemented as a regular REST API and expects its clients (such as a Logic app) to poll it in order to get notification.

trans-unit.source: While the client may maintain state, the poll trigger itself is stateless.
trans-unit.target: While the client may maintain state, the poll trigger itself is stateless.

trans-unit.source: The following information regarding the request and response packets illustrate some key aspects of the poll trigger contract:
trans-unit.target: The following information regarding the request and response packets illustrate some key aspects of the poll trigger contract:

trans-unit.source: Request
trans-unit.target: Request

trans-unit.source: HTTP method: GET
trans-unit.target: HTTP method: GET

trans-unit.source: Parameters
trans-unit.target: Parameters

trans-unit.source: - triggerState - This optional parameter allows clients to specify their state so that the poll trigger can properly decide whether to return notification or not based on the specified state.
trans-unit.target: - triggerState - This optional parameter allows clients to specify their state so that the poll trigger can properly decide whether to return notification or not based on the specified state.

trans-unit.source: - API-specific parameters
trans-unit.target: - API-specific parameters

trans-unit.source: Response
trans-unit.target: Response

trans-unit.source: Status code 200 - Request is valid and there is a notification from the trigger.
trans-unit.target: Status code 200 - Request is valid and there is a notification from the trigger.

trans-unit.source: The content of the notification will be the response body.
trans-unit.target: The content of the notification will be the response body.

trans-unit.source: A "Retry-After" header in the response indicates that additional notification data must be retrieved with a subsequent request call.
trans-unit.target: A "Retry-After" header in the response indicates that additional notification data must be retrieved with a subsequent request call.

trans-unit.source: Status code 202 - Request is valid, but there is no new notification from the trigger.
trans-unit.target: Status code 202 - Request is valid, but there is no new notification from the trigger.

trans-unit.source: Status code 4xx - Request is not valid.
trans-unit.target: Status code 4xx - Request is not valid.

trans-unit.source: The client should not retry the request.
trans-unit.target: The client should not retry the request.

trans-unit.source: Status code 5xx - Request has resulted in an internal server error and/or temporary issue.
trans-unit.target: Status code 5xx - Request has resulted in an internal server error and/or temporary issue.

trans-unit.source: The client should retry the request.
trans-unit.target: The client should retry the request.

trans-unit.source: The following code snippet is an example of how to implement a poll trigger.
trans-unit.target: The following code snippet is an example of how to implement a poll trigger.

trans-unit.source: To test this poll trigger, follow these steps:
trans-unit.target: To test this poll trigger, follow these steps:

trans-unit.source: Deploy the API App with an authentication setting of public anonymous.
trans-unit.target: Deploy the API App with an authentication setting of public anonymous.

trans-unit.source: Call the touch operation to touch a file.
trans-unit.target: Call the touch operation to touch a file.

trans-unit.source: The following image shows a sample request via Postman.
trans-unit.target: The following image shows a sample request via Postman.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Call Touch Operation via Postman</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Call Touch Operation via Postman</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Call the poll trigger with the triggerState parameter set to a time stamp prior to Step #2.
trans-unit.target: Call the poll trigger with the triggerState parameter set to a time stamp prior to Step #2.

trans-unit.source: The following image shows the sample request via Postman.
trans-unit.target: The following image shows the sample request via Postman.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Call Poll Trigger via Postman</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Call Poll Trigger via Postman</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Push trigger
trans-unit.target: Push trigger

trans-unit.source: A push trigger is implemented as a regular REST API that pushes notifications to clients who have registered to be notified when specific events fire.
trans-unit.target: A push trigger is implemented as a regular REST API that pushes notifications to clients who have registered to be notified when specific events fire.

trans-unit.source: The following information regarding the request and response packets illustrate some key aspects of the push trigger contract.
trans-unit.target: The following information regarding the request and response packets illustrate some key aspects of the push trigger contract.

trans-unit.source: Request
trans-unit.target: Request

trans-unit.source: HTTP method: PUT
trans-unit.target: HTTP method: PUT

trans-unit.source: Parameters
trans-unit.target: Parameters

trans-unit.source: - triggerId: required - Opaque string (such as a GUID) that represents the registration of a push trigger.
trans-unit.target: - triggerId: required - Opaque string (such as a GUID) that represents the registration of a push trigger.

trans-unit.source: - callbackUrl: required - URL of the callback to invoke when the event fires.
trans-unit.target: - callbackUrl: required - URL of the callback to invoke when the event fires.

trans-unit.source: The invocation is a simple POST HTTP call.
trans-unit.target: The invocation is a simple POST HTTP call.

trans-unit.source: - API-specific parameters
trans-unit.target: - API-specific parameters

trans-unit.source: Response
trans-unit.target: Response

trans-unit.source: Status code 200 - Request to register client successful.
trans-unit.target: Status code 200 - Request to register client successful.

trans-unit.source: Status code 4xx - Request is not valid.
trans-unit.target: Status code 4xx - Request is not valid.

trans-unit.source: The client should not retry the request.
trans-unit.target: The client should not retry the request.

trans-unit.source: Status code 5xx - Request has resulted in an internal server error and/or temporary issue.
trans-unit.target: Status code 5xx - Request has resulted in an internal server error and/or temporary issue.

trans-unit.source: The client should retry the request.
trans-unit.target: The client should retry the request.

trans-unit.source: Callback
trans-unit.target: Callback

trans-unit.source: HTTP method: POST
trans-unit.target: HTTP method: POST

trans-unit.source: Request body: Notification content.
trans-unit.target: Request body: Notification content.

trans-unit.source: The following code snippet is an example of how to implement a push trigger:
trans-unit.target: The following code snippet is an example of how to implement a push trigger:

trans-unit.source: To test this poll trigger, follow these steps:
trans-unit.target: To test this poll trigger, follow these steps:

trans-unit.source: Deploy the API App with an authentication setting of public anonymous.
trans-unit.target: Deploy the API App with an authentication setting of public anonymous.

trans-unit.source: Browse to <link><linkText>http://requestb.in/</linkText><title></title></link> to create a RequestBin which will serve as your callback URL.
trans-unit.target: Browse to <link><linkText>http://requestb.in/</linkText><title></title></link> to create a RequestBin which will serve as your callback URL.

trans-unit.source: Call the push trigger with a GUID as triggerId and the RequestBin URL as callbackUrl.
trans-unit.target: Call the push trigger with a GUID as triggerId and the RequestBin URL as callbackUrl.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Call Push Trigger via Postman</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Call Push Trigger via Postman</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Call the touch operation to touch a file.
trans-unit.target: Call the touch operation to touch a file.

trans-unit.source: The following image shows a sample request via Postman.
trans-unit.target: The following image shows a sample request via Postman.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Call Touch Operation via Postman</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Call Touch Operation via Postman</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Check the RequestBin to confirm that the push trigger callback is invoked with property output.
trans-unit.target: Check the RequestBin to confirm that the push trigger callback is invoked with property output.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Call Poll Trigger via Postman</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Call Poll Trigger via Postman</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Describe triggers in API definition
trans-unit.target: Describe triggers in API definition

trans-unit.source: After implementing the triggers and deploying your API app to Azure, navigate to the API Definition blade in the Azure preview portal and you'll see that triggers are automatically recognized in the UI, which is driven by the Swagger 2.0 API definition of the API app.
trans-unit.target: After implementing the triggers and deploying your API app to Azure, navigate to the API Definition blade in the Azure preview portal and you'll see that triggers are automatically recognized in the UI, which is driven by the Swagger 2.0 API definition of the API app.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>API Definition Blade</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>API Definition Blade</linkText>

trans-unit.source: If you click the Download Swagger button and open the JSON file, you'll see results similar to the following:
trans-unit.target: If you click the Download Swagger button and open the JSON file, you'll see results similar to the following:

trans-unit.source: The extension property x-ms-schedular-trigger is how triggers are described in API definition, and is automatically added by the API app gateway when you request the API definition via the gateway if the request to one of the following criteria.
trans-unit.target: The extension property x-ms-schedular-trigger is how triggers are described in API definition, and is automatically added by the API app gateway when you request the API definition via the gateway if the request to one of the following criteria.

trans-unit.source: (You can also add this property manually.)
trans-unit.target: (You can also add this property manually.)

trans-unit.source: Poll trigger
trans-unit.target: Poll trigger

trans-unit.source: If the HTTP method is GET.
trans-unit.target: If the HTTP method is GET.

trans-unit.source: If the operationId property contains the string trigger.
trans-unit.target: If the operationId property contains the string trigger.

trans-unit.source: If the parameters property includes a parameter with a name property set to triggerState.
trans-unit.target: If the parameters property includes a parameter with a name property set to triggerState.

trans-unit.source: Push trigger
trans-unit.target: Push trigger

trans-unit.source: If the HTTP method is PUT.
trans-unit.target: If the HTTP method is PUT.

trans-unit.source: If the operationId property contains the string trigger.
trans-unit.target: If the operationId property contains the string trigger.

trans-unit.source: If the parameters property includes a parameter with a name property set to triggerId.
trans-unit.target: If the parameters property includes a parameter with a name property set to triggerId.

trans-unit.source: Use API app triggers in Logic apps
trans-unit.target: Use API app triggers in Logic apps

trans-unit.source: List and configure API app triggers in the Logic apps designer
trans-unit.target: List and configure API app triggers in the Logic apps designer

trans-unit.source: If you create a Logic app in the same resource group as the API app, you will be able to add it to the designer canvas simply by clicking it.
trans-unit.target: If you create a Logic app in the same resource group as the API app, you will be able to add it to the designer canvas simply by clicking it.

trans-unit.source: The following images illustrate this:
trans-unit.target: The following images illustrate this:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Triggers in Logic App Designer</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Triggers in Logic App Designer</linkText>

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Configure Poll Trigger in Logic App Designer</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Configure Poll Trigger in Logic App Designer</linkText>

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Configure Push Trigger in Logic App Designer</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Configure Push Trigger in Logic App Designer</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Optimize API app triggers for Logic apps
trans-unit.target: Optimize API app triggers for Logic apps

trans-unit.source: After you add triggers to an API app, there are a few things you can do to improve the experience when using the API app in a Logic app.
trans-unit.target: After you add triggers to an API app, there are a few things you can do to improve the experience when using the API app in a Logic app.

trans-unit.source: For instance, the triggerState parameter for poll triggers should be set to the following expression in the Logic app.
trans-unit.target: For instance, the triggerState parameter for poll triggers should be set to the following expression in the Logic app.

trans-unit.source: This expression should evaluate the last invocation of the trigger from the Logic app, and return that value.
trans-unit.target: This expression should evaluate the last invocation of the trigger from the Logic app, and return that value.

trans-unit.source: NOTE: For an explanation of the functions used in the expression above, refer to the documentation on <link><linkText>Logic App Workflow Definition Language</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: NOTE: For an explanation of the functions used in the expression above, refer to the documentation on <link><linkText>Logic App Workflow Definition Language</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Logic app users would need to provide the expression above for the triggerState parameter while using the trigger.
trans-unit.target: Logic app users would need to provide the expression above for the triggerState parameter while using the trigger.

trans-unit.source: It is possible to have this value preset by the Logic app designer through the extension property x-ms-scheduler-recommendation.
trans-unit.target: It is possible to have this value preset by the Logic app designer through the extension property x-ms-scheduler-recommendation.

trans-unit.source: The x-ms-visibility extension property can be set to a value of internal so that the parameter itself is not shown on the designer.
trans-unit.target: The x-ms-visibility extension property can be set to a value of internal so that the parameter itself is not shown on the designer.

trans-unit.source: The following snippet illustrates that.
trans-unit.target: The following snippet illustrates that.

trans-unit.source: For push triggers, the triggerId parameter must uniquely identify the Logic app.
trans-unit.target: For push triggers, the triggerId parameter must uniquely identify the Logic app.

trans-unit.source: A recommended best practice is to set this property to the name of the workflow by using the following expression:
trans-unit.target: A recommended best practice is to set this property to the name of the workflow by using the following expression:

trans-unit.source: Using the x-ms-scheduler-recommendation and x-ms-visibility extension properties in its API definiton, the API app can convey to the Logic app designer to automatically set this expression for the user.
trans-unit.target: Using the x-ms-scheduler-recommendation and x-ms-visibility extension properties in its API definiton, the API app can convey to the Logic app designer to automatically set this expression for the user.

trans-unit.source: Add extension properties in API defintion
trans-unit.target: Add extension properties in API defintion

trans-unit.source: Additional metadata information - such as the extension properties x-ms-scheduler-recommendation and x-ms-visibility - can be added in the API defintion in one of two ways: static or dynamic.
trans-unit.target: Additional metadata information - such as the extension properties x-ms-scheduler-recommendation and x-ms-visibility - can be added in the API defintion in one of two ways: static or dynamic.

trans-unit.source: For static metadata, you can directly edit the /metadata/apiDefinition.swagger.json file in your project and add the properties manually.
trans-unit.target: For static metadata, you can directly edit the /metadata/apiDefinition.swagger.json file in your project and add the properties manually.

trans-unit.source: For API apps using dynamic metadata, you can edit the SwaggerConfig.cs file to add an operation filter which can add these extensions.
trans-unit.target: For API apps using dynamic metadata, you can edit the SwaggerConfig.cs file to add an operation filter which can add these extensions.

trans-unit.source: The following is an example of how this class can be implemented to facilitate the dynamic metadata scenario.
trans-unit.target: The following is an example of how this class can be implemented to facilitate the dynamic metadata scenario.
